thread.title: Yanks notes: Back troubles slow Ellsbury, Headley - Baseball
thread.title_full: Yanks notes: Back troubles slow Ellsbury, Headley - Baseball - NorthJersey.com

author: The Record
title: Yanks notes: Back troubles slow Ellsbury, Headley - Baseball
text:
Back troubles 
Jacoby Ellsbury's back was bothering him Thursday, prompting manager Joe Girardi to leave the center fielder out of the lineup.
Ellsbury jumped and hit the wall back-first while attempting to make a catch in Wednesday night's loss to the Red Sox.
"He's a little sore after he hit the wall," Girardi said. "I knew he was sore when he hit the wall."
Girardi also said that Chase Headley's back began giving him problems after Wednesday night's game.
"His back's stiff, too," Girardi said. "He kind of locked up a little bit. He's going to go through treatment … and we'll see where he's at."
After the game, Headley said he would be ready to play today. Girardi said Ellsbury would have been available Thursday if needed.
Tanaka on track 
Masahiro Tanaka struggled Wednesday, pitching after a 12-day layoff because of a hamstring injury. But Girardi said Tanaka came out of the start without any additional physical concerns — putting him on track for a start in Tuesday's wild-card game.
"He said his leg felt good," Girardi said. "I felt he was a little bit rusty [Wednesday], but he'll be able to throw a normal bullpen here in a few days, and he felt good."
Comeback Alex? 
Alex Rodriguez, who missed all of last season because of a suspension for performance-enhancing drugs, has apparently impressed his peers with his surprising season.
On Thursday, the Major League Baseball Players Association — which A-Rod sued in 2013 in an effort to get his suspension overturned — chose Rodriguez as one of three finalists for the Players' Choice American League Comeback Player of the Year.
The other two finalists are Texas' Prince Fielder and Kansas City's Kendrys Morales.
— Andy Vasquez
